reviewText: Let me address some obvious expectations from the cover art and because of the title.  This DVD does not contain nudity of the actress portraying Belle.  It is also quite far from being appropriate for children.  The story is partially narrated as if this were a fairy tale, but with the violence, gore, and demon-troll conjured up by a sorceress with many potions, powders, candles, daggers, witchcraft of a dark nature, and spite; let's just say this is not a bedtime story.  Rated R, this 2010 film is said to be a suspense / fantasy / thriller starring Estella Warren, Rhett Giles, Victor Parascos, Vanessa Gray, Tony Bellette, Chris Betts, Rachel Binder, Rachel Clark, Gabriella Di Labio, and was filmed in the Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia and Warner Bros Movieworld - Pacific Highway, Oxenford, Queensland, Australia.  Directed by David Lister, this 90 minute movie has many versions that besides the USA was also shown in Greece, Lebanon, Germany, Belgium, Netherlands, and India and France.  There aren't any pitchfork impalements, and the FX for the beheadings isn't all that impressive.  From what I understand, this was on TV's SyFy channel.  Most fans of the traditional story know there are many, many productions using the name "Beauty and the Beast," my favorites include the 1976 version with George C. Scott, of course the Disney version in 1991, and the 1967 TV series with Ron Perlman as Vincent and Linda Hamilton as Catherine.  Let me be clear, THIS particular DVD presentation is not among that list.  It will take being a seriously enthusiastic fan of the Beauty and the Beast genre to get much out of this DVD version.  On the other hand, I enjoyed how this version deals with the sorceress.

Beauty and the Beast: A Dark Tale is a small budget movie that despite its flaws and 'smallness' turns out to be pretty good. Don't look for some perfect, grandiose movie and you might find something interesting here! The classic fairy tale of Beauty and the Beast in this movie is told as a "dark tale" but has the traditional happy ending.

Technically the movie was not all there (like the editing being confusing at times, and sometimes the lighting/photography was not good, with some scenes looking bland or washed), but i found the basic story, characters and the basic sense of it to be very good.

Rhett Giles as Count Rudolph and Vanessa Gray as Lady Helen (the "witch" - a "fairy" in the original 18th century tale turns the prince into the beast) make a good bad couple.

Estella Warren as Belle (the beauty) and Victor Parascos as the Beast are wonderful.

Their relationships and roles are well done and interesting.

ps:

the bonus features include some fun interviews with the main actors, make-up artist and director.

rated R for violent images; namely a "troll" killing and eating people.

I disagree with other reviews. I did expected it to be a different kind of a movie. And yes the graphics were not the best. But if you've seen computer graphics, then you'd say that they look good. As for the deaths, there are many cut scenes that don't basically show you how the people got attacked and murdered by the beast. And the wounds, cut off heads look cheap but not as cheap as in many other low budget movies. It looks unreal but it doesn't look that bad. The acting is actually not bad at all. The witch might some more practice in acting as a witch but as for other characters, I'd say they did good, but could do better. The movie gives away it's own atmosphere. I like the dark fairy tale. I'd say, there are good actors, actresses in here. I like how they've changed the tale. For the low budget movie it was pretty good!

This Beauty and the Beast is a very different take on the well known Fairy Tale.  The King is near death and needs an heir, as his son had died as an infant.  This movie has lots of twists and turns involving evil relatives, witch, deadly troll, a horribly twisted and scared man in the woods and a beautiful girl named Beauty.  However, nothing is ever what it seems.  It eventually has a happy ending, with the message that goodness overcomes evil.  It is not appropriate for teens or children, strictly for adults. It may appeal to individuals enjoying a darker type of story.
Wow...when I saw the trailer I thought it would be ok. The movie was terrible! The acting sucked and it seemed so rushed. I'll be re-gifting this.

How can you prove your innocence if everyone thinks your guilty.  After many townspeople wind up dead, the Beast (Parascos) is blamed.  Belle (Warren) and her father know the truth but it may be too late to help.  Where to begin....This movie was lame.  It reminded me a lot of the "Hercules" and "Xena" TV shows, without the witty dialog.  It was a made for TV movie (I think) so I can't be too harsh on the effects, but when someone's head gets cut off and 2 little squirts of blood show up, I mean come on.  I think this one was rushed out to coincide with the movie "Beastly" that is in theaters, and it shows (that it was rushed).  I was not expecting a lot from this, but it was really, really bad.  Ill stick with the cartoon.  There were really only two reasons I kept watching, you will know why when you see this.  It's actually almost worth watching to see how bad it is.  I give it a D.

Would I watch again? - Never again will I watch this

I don't know how this movie made it to Amazon Prime, WTH, horrible acting!!!
I could not even finish the beginning. I could see the hair extension on the woman.
It doesn't even deserve one star....

3 stars is more than this movie deserve-it was not okay.  A bad "B" movie with a a horrible ending, bad acting , bad writing, bad editing, even very bad hair extensions on "Sven" who should have been billed 4th instead of "the beast"..  Bad costumes-what were they thinking? Viking women wearing purple silk and fitted gowns from the 18th century?  I don't really know the wardrobe of viking men or women but it's highly doubtful. Even the mens costumes were overly adorned with studded gold inlayed on leather.  . .  even the island was tropical instead of set in the northern hemisphere. Beauty and the beast---the beast was billed 4th, umm he's a major character. Where were the scenes that establish a relationship between the beautiful women and this beast?  Where is the scene that casts him out of her life?  All I saw was some guy saying "I will come back for you..." . A very long film, tragically long. The story does has potential but the sad lack of imagination to tell a story and grab the imaginations of the viewer is lost from the very beginnings of this film. The actors are swimming in a river , jumping from an apparatus that could not have existed in the supposed tie the film took place . . . Lots can be be forgiven in film making but not much of this film is worth saving. I don't know how any of it made it to the screen.
yech. Awful. You know a movie is bad when you start doing other things during the first 10 minutes.

I have a soft spot for B movies that aren't trying too hard to be A level. This version of Beauty and the Beast is endearingly awful with a costume vibe reminiscent of Zena: Warrior Princess. Disney B&B lovers should probably steer clear due to its gore, dark nature, and needless random sticks (what are they for? there is no structural need for so many lets just call it visual texture!!). I agree with those reviewers distracted by the wigs.  I was positively mesmerized by Svens frontal rat tail- a Viking Anglerfish!  This film is recommended only to those that delight in the absurd.  I would suggest an accompanying drinking game- one shot every time the name ODIN is uttered. Be warned, participants will need to be rushed to the emergency room for alcohol poisoning by midpoint!
I could get past the cheesy parts but the ending was depressing

This little gem would have been perfect for Joel and the Bots on the Satellite of Love.
It's like a local community college got the entire theater and art departments together for one huge senior project in the 90s.  Seriously, the wigs are so bad it will make you question your sanity.  But as a die-hard MST3K fan, I love this kind of stuff!  And I actually got sort of interested in the plot toward the end.  If so-bad-it's-good is your cup of tea, put this in your list, you won't regret it.
I couldn't even watch it, the quality was so poor on this site.

I couldn't even get past the first 20 minutes before I began to dread going any further.  I realized it's a low budget film but damn, the woman didn't dress like that and the men didn't wear armor.  Amor wasn't worn until much later and when it was it wasn't worn like that.  If I could give this a no star rating I would but alas, it won't allow that.  I love period flicks, I love history, I love Vikings and I love the story of Beauty and the Beast so when I saw this I was interested but this one made me want to heave.  NO NO NO...just no.

Oh man, hilariously bad---to the point where it was kind of good. Honestly, it was the costumes and settings that got me the most. I couldn't tell if the story was supposed to be during the Viking ages, the Middle Ages, or 90s prom (the flowers look like butterfly hair clippies). You gotta appreciate how incredibly bad the wigs are.

It was just so bad--but I admit I watched the whole thing while I was doing laundry.
Norse like fantasy, it was pretty good. The acting was good and the settings seemed authentic. I just wished the ending wasn't so tragic. At least it leaves you with a resolution.
An Viking twist in the French tale of B&B.  Watch with the mindset that this isn't Disney's musical adaptation, and use toothpicks to keep the eyes open.
Awful acting. Horrible camera work. Dissatisfying ending.
It was on Sci Fi and I didn't realize until I started watching it. LOL
Love this movies. Ao glad that i ordered it.
Ok
Good movie! Obviously not exactly like the original cartoon, which is my favorite movie of ALL movies, but it is a good movie!! And for the price, awesome, thank you!!!

I've been on a roll for along time picking good to excellent movies to add to the DVD collection. I missed the boat here. There really is nothing redeeming about this movie. No acting ... No clever twists to the original story ... It's  most redeeming assets were Estella Warrens' Boobs and lets face it .., There are no brains or acting ability there. OOPS , the DVD just fell off my desk into the trash ...Oh well..
I loved the movie a good fairy tail and the acting was good too.

I liked this version of Beauty and the Beast. The makeup on the Beast was well done. Belle's costuming was obviously made for males to ogle. Her acting was not very good. It was a different story than the regular one most of us Beauty and the Beast fans know.
My kids loved it.
Very entertaining though a slightly different version of the classic story.  Wish it had been a bunch less bloody.
GOOD MOVIE I LOVE IT
seen this one tv soooo good
i love this movie and it is a wonderful part of my movie collection

Will history teach us nothing? I've had cohorts and minions try to warn me off this Syfy flick. But, going in, all I ever saw was Estella Warren. But they were right, omigosh, were they right. 2009's Beauty & the Beast: A Dark Tale (a.k.a. Beauty & the Beasts, a.k.a. Beauty & the Beast: A Jumped-Up SKit at the Renaissance Fair - okay, maybe not this second one) is a worthwhile watch only if you're chillin' with your sardonic lads and a kegger or two into your cups. But I should've listened to my homies. This movie opens in the royal chambers of some nondescript castle as relatives of no mean ambition hover like vultures over the death bed of ancient King Maximillian XIII, awaiting the naming of his heir. The expiring king mumbles something about fetching his son, and you see the folks gathered trade nonplussed expressions, because the king's son had died many years ago. Focus now on some nondescript village and into one humble abode. There, the washerwoman's adventurous daughter Belle (Warren) has her latest concoction - essence of oak, oil of pine, camphor leaf - ignite in her face, black smoke pluming in the household (and can you doubt that this accidental smoke bomb will resurface later on?). Off Belle goes to the forest to collect more ingredients, and she promptly runs into monsters. If this is director David Lister's bid for darker twist on the Beauty and the Beast fable, well, he bo11ocksed it up. This is Lister's second stab at Beauty and the Beast, having done a Viking version in 2005 titled Blood of Beasts - and even THAT was better than this. The core plot of this one has the Beast (Victor Parascos) framed for the savage murders of errant villagers. What the locals don't know is that the culprit is a troll conjured up by the comely Lady Helen of Osberg (a theatrical Vanessa Gray) who is reputed to be a foul witch. The Beast himself is a reclusive woodsman and hunter with a mutated countenance. Give Belle credit now for not succumbing to first impressions. Well, yeah, at first she freaks out. But wouldn't you, too? You know the classic story. At least the director keeps faith with that arc. So sit back as Lister tries to spin a tale as old as time except, in his version, Belle flaunts a pair of Botox lips and strolls around in a mini-skirt accented with a brown vinyl corset. Uh, on second thought, verisimilitude be damned, I'm okay with Estella Warren in that inappropriate outfit. Her looking so good in a mini-skirt is what redeems her just-right-for-Syfy acting. I will say that for as much as Belle is victimized here, she has an equal number of scenes in which she handles her business. Of the acting, I'll mention that the best of the lot is Rhett Giles as the ruthless Count Rudolph, and even Giles was reaching. There's no point in savaging the film. Let's leave it at that the screenplay is underdeveloped and amateurish. The CGI is embarrassing and poorly implemented; the troll looks like a pissed-off plucked turkey. Anachronism is the watchword of the day as the cast speaks in very non-medieval dialogue. I did like one rival mockingly calling Count Rudolph "Rudy." All these flaws could have been dismissed if only the two leads were able to muster up sparks. Instead, their romance feels very forced and tagged on. And, oh, what the hell, let's do keep on savaging the film. A few take-away notes: - I hope the film crew returned the LARP costumes in time - In the witch's lair Belle grabs a random potion off the witch's worktable to apply to her friend's fatal wound... because it's the smart thing to do - Okay, this one's really nitpicky but I dare you not to snort when the Beast's curse is lifted and he turns into a handsome prince, but so do the Beast's filthy rags shimmer into royal garments - High, high up on the tower rests the witch's lair but not high enough that Belle couldn't casually and accurately lob a smoke bomb into its window

This movie is completely a B rated film, but I always like terrible movies. The story is good enough and the idea is well played. However, when there are mythical creatures present like dragons you can definitely tell it's completely fake. If you have good imagination this film can work for you, if you don't just know that this isn't a blockbuster film.
It is a different take on the Beauty and the Beast story. It's more scarier version than the original version

The narrator of this film tells us that by watching what he put together we will finally  thank God  get to know the true story of what happened to this famous couple. He says this is a forbidden story between a maiden and a monster  whatever that means. There is a monster who is blamed for brutally killing many people, although he is innocent; in fact he is very nice. Someone or something else is killing the villagers. The beast saves a beautiful girl with partially exposed breasts, a very short skirt, and a leather shirt.

This true story happened in the middle ages when two evil people lived, a witch and a count. The king of the state dies and the cruel count wants to be king. The witch wants to marry him so she can have even more power than she currently has. She promises the count that she can help him catch the beast and become a hero who the villagers will want as their king.

We wait with batted breath to find out who is the beast, how did he become a beast, will he become human with a kiss, how can normal people overcome a witch?
I was really disappointed in this movie but, again, it was my choice to purchase it.  I have all the other Beauty and the Beast movies so needed this one to complete my set.

I first found out about this 2011 film the other day browsing at the video rental store and picked it up. I really thought it was pretty good. I would rate it almost on a par with an episode of the TV series Legend of the Seeker, though that series has somewhat better writing and production quality.

I think Estella Warren is simply fabulous. She's a bit of a struggling actress from a former career in modeling and if I recall correctly, a history as an athlete from her native Canada... Many good actresses and actors don't have the option of choosing from premium scripts and starring roles like the A list people do, and they must settle for films like this and do the best they can with them.

When I saw Estella in the 2001 Mark Wahlberg remake of Planet of the Apes I thought she was great too, but she didn't get much attention or the best role in my opinion, as she was overshadowed by Helena Bonham Carter's character.

So Estella's acting may not be on a par with the top actresses of our day, but I think she does a pretty bang up job with what she gets offered, and she just seems to me like a real sweetheart. I'd pretty much watch anything she has a role in just to see her.

The story itself has a somewhat unique twist on the Beauty and the Beast theme and they obviously went to some effort to get the "period" setting correct in the film with costumes, armor etc, though the special effects and gore might have been a bit off to the taste of many. Overall though the cast did a good job with what they had before them.

You have to expect that any movie that doesn't get huge box office attention is probably not going to be something that is extremely moving or deep drama. Just sit back with some popcorn and enjoy this for the fun romp into a twisted fantasy world that it is.

And tell me afterwards if you wouldn't want the wench, the trollop, riding on horseback with YOU through the forests searching for the Beast!

Among the extras on the DVD are interviews with the cast, and Estella's focuses on the fact that she talks about how most women would like to be the fair maiden in a fantasy world drama, and that's what drew her to the role... That's a good attitude to have for a B film like this, and I can think of no one better to fill such a role than her.
This is a slightly different version of Disney's tale, but very much enjoyed it.
The acting and the story in itself is a little bit weak, but somehow loved it. Loved seeing a classic story from a twisted angle...
I have no words for how utterly atrocious this was. No plot, bad research... just. Wow.
Crappy actors, poor story line, waste of time

Oh my gosh... Wow. Honestly, 3 stars is charitable. I'll give it points for having an original concept for a B&B retelling. The Viking thing was different. I hadn't seen that done before. That's about all I can say in its favor. The costumes were terrible. Clearly historically incorrect, to the untrained eye. The guys honestly looked like they just got off a bus heading back from comic-con. Wigs and all. The women were wearing basically whatever costumes they pass around for every b-rated fantasy film. The acting was mediocre, at best. I think it just sounded as bad as it did because the dialogue was awful. Like worse than Star Wars prequel movies dialogue. Very over done and forced. I don't know how they read their lines with a straight face. My favorite had to be when the beast said, "Freya, I'm confused", because honestly dude, same. The ending surprised me, not exactly in a good way. It was less predictable than other certain elements. All in all, not a great watch, but adequate to pass the time.
I couldn't even get through the first 15 minutes.
An unusual telling of Beauty and the Beast. Very Dark. Clothing not historically accurate. Very unusual twist to the story at the end.

If you want a very creative, loose interpretation of "vikings" and "acting," then this is the movie for you!  Don't let the title fool you: it doesn't end well like the fairy tale.  It just doesn't really do anything well, to be honest, which I think might be the secret to its charm. Sadly, I don't think Amazon offers refunds on the hour and a half of your life that you will never get back.
A darker-side of a favorite fairy tale.

an interesting take on the fairy tale.  small cast, (a pretty small clan there) but a solid group well done.  several characters (like the "gaston" Sven) are written a little 2-dimensional, but the lead and the main supports are done well.
